questions.text: A patient presented with palpable breast lump. On examination a mobile mass was palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Given below is the mammogram of the same patient. What is the diagnosing feature helping in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fibroadenoma is a common benign breast lesion characterized by excessive proliferation of connective tissue.

Typical Presentation

  • Most commonly occurs in women of reproductive
  • Mobile, palpable breast lump.
  • Fibroadenomas often enlarge during pregnancy and shrink after menopause, making them rare in women over 40.

Radiographic Features

Mammography:

  • Well-Circumscribed Oval Mass: Typically, hypo- or isodense relative to breast glandular tissue, and are lobulated
  • Involuting Fibroadenomas: May show Calcification, commonly appears as coarse popcorn-like calcifications.

Ultrasound

  • Appearance:
    • Well-Circumscribed Mass: Typically, round to ovoid or lobulated, Hypoechogenic and Intralesional Calcifications can be seen
    • Pseudocapsule (A thin echogenic rim may be seen around the mass.)

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Fibroadenoma are benign breast tumors.
  • Patient presence with mobile lump typically described as lumpy bumpy, breast, or breast mouse.
  • Associated with Med 12 mutation.
  • Shows popcorn calcification on USG

questions.text: A patient presented with breast pain. She was advised to undergo a mammogram which showed microcalcifications in the breast image. The physician advised to undergo an ultrasound examination which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a non-invasive breast carcinoma confined to the ducts, without invasion beyond the basement membrane.

Risk Factors

  • Increasing Age
  • Family History:
  • Nulliparity:
  • Late First Pregnancy

Mammographic Manifestations

  • Casting-Type Calcifications: The most common finding, present in 50-75% of cases.
  • Soft-Tissue Opacity: May appear with or without associated calcifications.

Types of Calcifications

  • Linear Calcifications: More likely associated with comedo-type DCIS.
  • Granular Calcifications: Often correlated with non-comedo DCIS.

Ultrasound Findings

  • Sonographic Abnormalities: Identification of ultrasound findings in women with mammographically detected DCIS aids in guiding interventional procedures (e.g., biopsy or hook wire placement).
  • Common Features:
    • Microlobulated Mild Hypoechoic Mass: Typically shows ductal extension and normal acoustic transmission.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

questions.text: Identify the view of mammogram shown below
questions.solution:
Mammography can be categorized into two main groups: standard views and supplementary views.

Standard Views

  1. Bilateral Craniocaudal (CC) View: A view taken from above the breast, providing a top-down perspective.
  2. Mediolateral Oblique (MLO) View: Taken at an angle, this view allows for better visualization of the breast tissue and potential abnormalities.

Supplementary Views

Supplementary views are utilized to provide additional information or to address specific concerns that arise during standard imaging. These can include additional angles or specialized imaging techniques to investigate areas of suspicion. These include axillary views, rolled views etc.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Craniocaudal view only shows breast while Mediolateral oblique view shows both breast and axilla.

questions.text: A middle aged women presented with postmenopausal bleeding and lower abdominal pain. She was advised to undergo a USG examination. On doing an USG, the following image was obtained. It showed an enlarged uterus with thickening endometrium. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Endometrial hyperplasia is characterized by the abnormal proliferation of endometrial glands and stroma, typically indicated by diffuse smooth thickening of the endometrium greater than 10 mm.

Ultrasound Assessment

Timing of Imaging; Performing ultrasound on days 5-10 of the menstrual cycle minimizes variability in endometrial thickness and provides more consistent measurements.

Premenopausal Considerations

  • Normal Endometrial Thickness:
    • Varies with the menstrual cycle stage, but generally:
      • Secretory Phase: A thickness of up to 15 mm is considered the upper limit of normal.
    • Exclusion of Hyperplasia:
      • Endometrial hyperplasia can be reliably excluded when the endometrium measures less than 8 mm.

Postmenopausal Considerations

  • Abnormal Thickness:
    • An endometrial thickness greater than 5 mm is considered abnormal and may warrant further evaluation.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Endometrial thickness measuring more than 15 mm in premenopausal women and more than 5 mm is considered endometrial hyperplasia,
  • which requires further investigations and should undergo endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy.
  • Venetian blind appearance seen in adenomyosis (striate effect)

Fibroid

questions.text: A patient presented with lower abdominal pain and amenorrhea since 3 months. She experienced multiple episodes of vomiting. A UPT was done which showed positive results. She underwent a USG examination which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis of a given USG image of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Molar pregnancies, or hydatidiform moles, are a common form of gestational trophoblastic disease, categorized into complete and partial moles based on the presence or absence of fetal tissue.

  • Complete Moles: Characterized by the absence of a fetus.
  • Partial Moles: Typically associated with an abnormal fetus, which may or may not be viable, and can lead to fetal demise.

Complete Mole Radiographic Features

Ultrasound

  • Uterine Findings:
    • Enlarged uterus.
    • Appears as an intrauterine mass with multiple cystic spaces, often described as having a "snowstorm" or "bunch of grapes" appearance.
  • Diagnostic Challenges:
    • May be difficult to diagnose in the first trimester; <50% are diagnosed during this period.
    • Can resemble a normal pregnancy or an empty gestational sac.
  • Associated Findings:
    • Bilateral theca lutein cysts may be visible.
    • Color Doppler may show high-velocity flow with low impedance.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Complete mole shows snowstorm appearance on USG with no fetal parts seen.

Fetal parts can be seen in partial mole.

questions.text: A patient presented with lower abdominal pain and irregular bleeding. She is trying for conception. The doctor advised a hysterosalpingography (HSG) examination, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct option is Bicornuate uterus. The provided image shows a hysterosalpingography (HSG) examination, a procedure that uses a contrast dye to visualize the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. The image clearly displays two distinct and widely divergent endometrial cavities, which is the classic characteristic of a bicornuate uterus.
  • A bicornuate uterus is a congenital Müllerian duct fusion defect where the two uterine horns fail to fuse completely, resulting in a heart-shaped uterus. This condition can lead to reproductive issues such as infertility, recurrent pregnancy loss, and menstrual irregularities.
  • On HSG, a bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus can appear very similar because both show two cavities. HSG cannot reliably distinguish between them, as it does not visualize the outer uterine contour. Therefore, while bicornuate is the best answer among the given options, the true differential diagnosis could also be a septate uterus.

Bicornuate:

Septate:

Explanation of Other Options:

Unicornuate uterus (Option A): This would show a small, single endometrial cavity that is elongated and deviated to one side, with only one fallopian tube opacified. The image shows two cavities, making this option incorrect.

Arcuate uterus (Option B): This is characterized by a mild concavity at the fundus of the uterus, with a single, normal-sized endometrial cavity. It is the least clinically significant anomaly.

T-shaped uterus (Option D): This is typically associated with in-utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES). The uterine cavity appears narrow and tubular, with a "T" shape, which is different from the wide divergence seen in the image.

Key Takeaway:

A bicornuate uterus is a type of congenital uterine anomaly that presents with two widely divergent endometrial cavities on a hysterosalpingography (HSG). It is an important diagnosis to consider in patients with infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pelvic inflammatory disease in fallopian tubes?
questions.solution:
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to a spectrum of infections and inflammatory conditions affecting the upper female genital tract, including the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.

Etiology

PID is often caused by sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Other non-STI pathogens can also contribute to PID, particularly after surgical procedures or childbirth.

Clinical Presentation

Symptoms of PID can vary widely and may include:

  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Abnormal vaginal discharge
  • Fever
  • Pain during intercourse
  • Irregular menstrual bleeding

Key Ultrasound Findings

  1. Distinction from Fluid-Filled Bowel Loops by Lack of Peristalsis, a dilated fallopian tube will not exhibit peristalsis.
  2. Low-Level Internal Echoes may indicate the presence of pus (pyosalpinx).
  3. Hydrosalpinx shows Anechoic Fluid
  4. Tubal Wall Thickness: A wall thickness of ≥5 mm suggests acute disease.

Tubal Wall Structures

  • Cogwheel Sign:
    • An anechoic "cogwheel-shaped" appearance in cross-section, indicative of thickened walls, primarily seen in acute disease.
  • Beads on a String Sign:
    • Hyperechoic mural nodules (2-3 mm) on cross-section of a distended tube, seen in chronic disease due to degenerated endosalpingeal folds.
  • Incomplete Septa:
    • Hyperechoic septa protruding from one wall but not reaching the opposite wall; observed in both acute and chronic disease but not discriminatory.

Waist Sign (Patel et al. Findings)

  • Tubular Fluid-Filled Mass:
    • Characterized by diametrically opposed indentations in the wall, referred to as the "waist sign." This sign has the highest likelihood ratio for distinguishing hydrosalpinx from other adnexal masses.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

choices.text: Presence of solid component with color flow

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important feature in determining the malignancy of cystic ovarian lesion?
questions.solution:
When evaluating cystic ovarian masses, certain sonographic characteristics can help predict the likelihood of malignancy.

Key Features Indicating Malignancy

  1. Solid Component with Doppler Flow:
    • The presence of a solid component within a cystic mass, especially when detectable blood flow is observed via Doppler imaging, is the most significant indicator of potential malignancy.
    • Larger solid components correlate with an increased risk of ovarian cancer.
  2. Small Solid Components:
    • Small soft tissue components are more typical of borderline or stage I ovarian carcinomas rather than advanced stages.
  3. Hyperechoic Tissue:
    • While the presence of hyperechoic tissue (such as in dermoid tumors) can indicate benign conditions, solid nodules or projections (often termed papillary projections or vegetations) raise suspicion for malignancy, especially if they show vascularity on Doppler.
  4. Focal Wall Thickening:
    • Thickening of the cyst wall is another concerning feature that may suggest malignancy.

ORADS is used for the same.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Presence of solid component within a cystic mass with detectable blood flow on doppler indicates potential malignancy.
  • Solid component is not exclusive to malignancy.
  • Absence of solid component almost excludes malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following artery is used in obstetrics doppler for growth restriction?
questions.solution:
Umbilical arterial (UA) Doppler assessment is a crucial tool in evaluating fetal well-being during the third trimester.

It is particularly useful for detecting signs of placental insufficiency and conditions like intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and suspected pre-eclampsia.

Key Concepts

Umbilical Arterial Waveform

  • Normal Pattern:
    • The typical umbilical arterial waveform has a "sawtooth" appearance, with continuous forward flow towards the placenta.
  • Abnormal Findings:
    • An abnormal waveform may show:
      • Absent Diastolic Flow: Indicates potential issues with placental function.
      • Reversed Diastolic Flow: A concerning sign that requires further evaluation.

Gestational Age Considerations

  • Before the 15th week of gestation, the absence of diastolic flow can be considered a normal finding.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Doppler waveforms of umbilical arteries.

questions.text: Nuchal translucency in the first trimester scan is done to detect the risk of?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency (NT) is an important measurement taken during the late first trimester to assess potential fetal abnormalities.

It refers to the fluid-filled space at the back of the fetal neck, typically measured between 11 weeks 3 days and 13 weeks 6 days.

Increased NT can indicate various conditions, including:

  • Aneuploidy (abnormal number of chromosomes)
  • Trisomies, such as Down syndrome
  • Turner syndrome
  • Congenital heart defects
  • Skeletal dysplasia
  • Miscarriage or fetal demise

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Nuchal translucency is a first trimester screening method for congenital anomalies.
  • Less than 3 mm is considered normal in the first trimester and less than 6 mm is considered normal in second and third trimester.
  • Most common anomaly in first trimester is an aneuploidy

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a dating scan?
questions.solution:
Assessing gestational age in the first trimester is crucial due to minimal biological variation in fetal size. The following key points summarize the assessment process:

  1. Gestational Sac Measurement: The first structure evaluated is the gestational sac. The Mean Sac Diameter (MSD) is typically used, calculated as the average of the length, width, and anteroposterior diameter.
  2. Yolk Sac: The presence of a yolk sac, observed without an embryo, indicates a gestational age of approximately 5.5 weeks.
  3. Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Once the embryo is visible, the CRL measurement becomes the primary method for determining gestational age. This involves measuring the greatest length from the head to the rump of the fetus using calipers.
  4. Accuracy: Estimations of gestational age based on these measurements can have a maximal error of about 3 to 7 days.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  1. First trimester scan is called a dating scan.
    • It is the best scan for gestational age.
  2. Secondary trimester scan is called a fetal anomaly scan.
  3. Third trimester scan is a growth scan.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most useful measure for estimating gestational age in a third trimester fetus?
questions.solution:
Fetal femur length (FL) is an essential biometric parameter for assessing fetal size and growth.

  1. Importance: FL is a reliable indicator used to estimate overall fetal length and weight, especially in the third trimester, where it provides a more accurate assessment of fetal growth.
  2. Clinical Relevance: Accurate FL measurements are crucial for monitoring fetal development and can help in detecting potential growth restrictions or abnormalities.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

First trimester = CRL

Second trimester = Biparietal diameter

Third trimester = femur length

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a first trimester scan. The radiologist doing the scan identified the following image and advised her to meet with her obstetrician as soon as possible. The following image was seen in USG. What is the most probable diagnosis for the fetus?
questions.solution:
• The lemon sign is an important antenatal imaging finding, characterized by an indentation of the frontal bone resembling the shape of a lemon.
  • It is most commonly associated with conditions affecting neural development.
  • The lemon sign generally disappears after 24 weeks of gestation. This change is attributed to increased rigidity of the fetal calvaria and potential increases in intracranial pressure due to conditions like hydrocephalus.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

The lemon sign is notably linked to:

  • Chiari II Malformation
  • Spina Bifida (seen in 90-98% of cases)
  • Encephalocele
  • Dandy-Walker Malformation
  • Thanatophoric Dysplasia
  • Cystic Hygroma

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a prenatal scan. The radiologist noted a hypoechoic structure near the kidneys. On further evaluation it was observed to be a dilated fetal pelviureteric junction. What is the fetus at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct option is Oligohydramnios. The finding of a dilated fetal pelviureteric junction indicates a pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction, which is the most common cause of fetal hydronephrosis.
  • The question asks for the complication the fetus is at risk of developing from this condition. If the PUJ obstruction is severe and bilateral, it can significantly reduce fetal urine production.
  • As fetal urine is the primary contributor to amniotic fluid in the later trimesters, this can lead to oligohydramnios. This condition is associated with serious risks such as pulmonary hypoplasia, limb deformities, and Potter sequence.
  • Pathologies leading to marked hydronephrosis (especially in the third trimester):
    • Posterior urethral valves (most common in males)
    • Congenital pelviureteric junction obstruction (leading cause)
    • Congenital vesicoureteric junction obstruction
    • Ureterocele(s)
    • Urethral agenesis
    • Congenital megaureter

Explanation of Other Options:

Medullary cystic kidney disease (Option A): This is incorrect because this is a genetic tubulointerstitial disorder and is not related to prenatal hydronephrosis from a PUJ obstruction.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option B): This is incorrect because renal cell carcinoma is an adult malignancy and is not a relevant fetal complication. 

Polyhydramnios (Option C): This is incorrect. Polyhydramnios is the opposite condition (excessive amniotic fluid) and is caused by different underlying issues like maternal diabetes or fetal esophageal atresia, not by a PUJ obstruction.

Key Takeaway:

In prenatal ultrasound, a dilated pelviureteric junction (PUJ obstruction) is a significant finding. The main risk to the fetus from this condition is oligohydramnios, which can result from impaired fetal urine output and can lead to major developmental issues.

questions.text: How many indications are there in form F according to the PCPNDT act?
questions.solution:
The Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition Of Sex Selection) Act (PCPNDT) is a crucial statute in India aimed at combating female feticide and improving the declining female sex ratio.

Absolute Prohibition:

  • Sex determination and selection are strictly prohibited.

Qualified Personnel:

  • Only qualified professionals are permitted to conduct these diagnostic tests.

Registration of Centers:

  • All centers/institutions conducting these tests must be registered under the PCPNDT Act.
  • Applications for registration must be submitted using Form A along with an application fee (INR 3,000-4,000).

Certification:

  • Approved applicants receive Form B, which serves as a registration certificate, valid for five years. This certificate must be prominently displayed at the center.
  • Renewal requests should be submitted using Form A one month before the certificate's expiration.
  • Rejected applications receive Form C as a rejection certificate.

Record Keeping:

  • All records, including referral slips, must be meticulously maintained.
  • A complete report of all tests conducted must be submitted to the appropriate authority by the 5th of the following month.

Notification of Changes:

  • Any changes in equipment, personnel, or address must be reported to the appropriate authority.

Public Notice:

  • Centers must display a notice clearly stating that sex determination/selection is prohibited by law.

Equipment Regulations:

  • The sale of equipment or machines used for sex determination is prohibited.

KEY TAKE AWAY:
